overview.short: Actinomyces species are Gram-positive, non-spore-forming, pleomorphic rods that commonly inhabit the human oral cavity, gastrointestinal tract, and female genital tract.
overview.clinical_context: Associated with chronic, suppurative infections (actinomycosis), often involving abscess formation and sinus tracts, typically in cervicofacial, thoracic, or abdominopelvic sites.

field_notes.Oxygen Requirement: Many Actinomyces are best recovered under anaerobic or microaerophilic conditions, but may tolerate oxygen depending on species and culture conditions.
field_notes.Colony Morphology: Colonies are often irregular and may appear rough or granular; prolonged incubation can accentuate characteristic appearances.
field_notes.Catalase: Typically catalase negative, helping distinguish from aerobic actinomycetes.

key_differentiators.notes: Gram-positive morphology separates Actinomyces from Gram-negative oral flora.
Non-motility supports Actinomyces over motile Gram-positive rods.
Non-spore forming supports Actinomyces in chronic abscess settings.

common_confusions.reason: Both can present as branching Gram-positive rods and cause chronic infections.
Overlapping Gram-positive rod morphology may confuse if branching is not described.

when_to_question_identification: Strong aerobic growth with catalase positivity suggests Nocardia or other aerobic actinomycetes.
Spore formation suggests Bacillus or Clostridium rather than Actinomyces.
